The core-shell Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts were prepared by impregnation-decomposition method, and were comparatively evaluated for dry reforming of methane (DRM) under the severe conditions of 700 °C, 0.1 MPa, CH4/CO2 molar ratio of 1 and gas hourly space velocity of 60000 mL∙g−1∙h−1. La2O3 covers on the surface of Ni/SiO2 to form complete shell and reacts with Ni species to form LaNiO3 perovskite. The La2O3 shell blocks a fraction of porous structure and covers a part of Ni nanoparticles, resulting in the decrease in Ni dispersion. The Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts exhibit higher CH4 activity (21.8 – 24.3 mmol∙(min∙m2∙g)−1Ni) than Ni/SiO2 (17.8 mmol∙(min∙m2∙g)−1Ni), attributable to the accelerated CH4 activation over the Ni sites on these catalysts. The catalytic stability of Ni/SiO2@La2O3 is significantly improved (k d = 0.0198 – 0.0276 h−1 vs k d = 0.0512 h−1 for Ni/SiO2), which can be well explained as the enhanced anti-sintering and anti-coking capacities. The enhanced anti-sintering capacity is attributed to the confinement effect of La2O3 shell on suppressing sintering. The consecutive temperature-programmed surface reaction results confirm that La2O3 shell simultaneously promotes the CH4 decomposition and CO2 dissociation, which is the significantly important reason for the high DRM activity and good anti-coking capacity. The promotional effect of La2O3 shell on CH4 decomposition and CO2 dissociation is closely related to the metallic Ni originated from the reduction of the formed LaNiO3 perovskite. These understanding provides an important guidance for design a high-performance core-shell Ni-based catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dry reforming of methane Nickel catalysts Core-shell structure La2O3 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Currently, the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere is continuously increasing, which is primarily originated from the massive consumption of fossil fuel [1,2]. The continuous increase in CO2 concentration results in global warming, climate change, and ecological-environmental problems [1], motivating the intensive research interest of developing valuable techniques to mitigate CO2 emission and/or re-utilize CO2 as carbon resource to produce useful chemicals [3]. Among the currently available technologies, dry reforming of methane (DRM, Eq. 1) has been identified as a promising strategy for mitigation greenhouse gas emission, which can simultaneously convert CO2 and CH4 to synthesis gas (syngas, H2 + CO) [4,5]. It is worth noting that the syngas with H2/CO molar ratio ≤ 1 can be directly used as the versatile raw material to produce acetic acid [6], dimethyl ether [7], and long-chain hydrocarbons [8], achieving the re-utilization of CO2 and indirect conversion of natural gas with the main component of CH4. (Eq. 1) C O 4 + C O 2 → 2 H 2 + 2 CO Δ H 298 K 0 = + 247.3 k J · m o l − 1 (Eq. 2) C H 4 → 2 H 2 + C Δ H 298 K 0 = + 75 k J · m o l − 1 (Eq. 3) 2 CO → C + C O 2 Δ H 298 K 0 = − 171 k J · m o l − 1 Ni-based catalysts are commonly regarded as the most potential DRM catalyst for the commercialization owing to its relatively high activity, lower cost, and wide availability compared to the noble metal catalyst [9–11]. Unfortunately, Ni-based catalysts encounter severe sintering and carbon deposition, leading to the rapid decay of activity [12,13]. In general, CH4 decomposition (Eq. 2) and CO disproportionation (Eq. 3) reactions are the primary source for carbon deposition. As a highly endothermic reaction, DRM requires high operating temperature (700 – 1000 °C) to achieve desired activity [14]. In the case of high reaction temperature, the carbon deposition primarily originates from CH4 decomposition [15]. Further investigations are revealed on carbon deposition is that the generation rate of carbon species from CH4 decomposition is higher than the elimination rate by active oxygen species from CO2 dissociation because of the lower dissociation energy for CH3−H bond than that of C=O bond for CO2 (439.3 kJ∙mol−1 vs 750 kJ∙mol−1) [16]. Furthermore, due to the lower Tammann temperature (581 °C), tiny Ni nanoparticles are prone to sintering to form large-sized particles at high reaction temperature, which will promote carbon deposition owing to the carbon islands formed on large Ni particles is more difficult to gasification than that on tiny Ni particles [17,18]. Therefore, under the premise of inhibiting sintering, adjusting the CH4 decomposition and/or CO2 dissociation to achieve a good balance between carbon generation and gasification rates can significantly improve the resistance towards coking and catalytic stability of Ni-based catalysts. Recently, Zhao and co-workers [19] have reported a highly stable low-temperature DRM Ni-Ir/MgAl2O4 catalysts with outstanding anti-sintering capacity, the mechanism of which can be explained as the achieved dynamic balance between carbon deposition and elimination on Ni-Ir alloy by suppressing CH4 decomposition and accelerating oxidation of carbon species, proving the reasonable for the above-mentioned strategy of preparing Ni-based catalyst with great anti-coking capacity. More importantly, these research results further confirm that the great anti-sintering capacity is critical for constructing the balance of carbon generation-elimination. Concerning the resistance towards sintering, the catalysts with special core-shell structure display distinguished advantage since the high temperature stability can be enhanced by the confinement effect originating from the active sites locate in the core part and embed within the shell [20]. Moreover, the core and/or shell materials can be tailored to acquire the best synergetic effect [21], which is beneficial to adjust the reaction behavior of DRM. Based on the above understanding, constructing the core-shell Ni-based catalysts with the metal oxide as shell will achieve the purpose that the confinement effect of oxide shell suppresses sintering, simultaneously, metal oxides promote the CO2 dissociation to accelerate carbon gasification. Indeed, the core-shell Ni-based catalysts have been proved to exhibit improved anti-sintering and anti-coking capacities [22]. For instance, covering a CeO2 shell on the surface of Ni-SiO2 clearly enhances the resistance towards sintering and coking over Ni-SiO2 catalysts for DRM, the mechanism of which is explained as the enhanced anti-sintering capacity and the accelerated oxidization of carbon species formed on the Ni particles [23]. The former relies on the confinement effect of CeO2 shell, and the latter is assigned to the active participation of oxygen species from CeO2 in carbon gasification. Similarly, this mechanism is also applicable for the enhanced resistance towards carbon deposition over the sandwiched SiO2@Ni@ZrO2 catalyst [24] and core-shell Ni-phyllosilicate@Ce1-xZrxO2 catalyst [25]. At the same time, La2O3 possesses high thermal stability, basicity, and better capacity of CO2 adsorption and dissociation, which plays a significant role in improving the resistance towards carbon deposition over Ni-based catalysts [26–29]. More importantly, the Ni-La2O3 interactions can be more strengthen with forming perovskite (LaNiO3 and/or La2NiO4) than other processes, effectively improving the resistance towards sintering [30]. Therefore, the promotional behaviors of constructing La2O3 shell for Ni-based catalyst probably differ from that of CeO2 or ZrO2, and the effect of the formed perovskite on the anti-coking capacity and catalytic activity is not clear, which are worth to deeply research. Based on these analyses, in this work, the core-shell Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts prepared by the simple impregnation-decomposition method were comparatively investigated for DRM under severe condition of 700 °C, 0.1 MPa, CH4/CO2 molar ratio = 1 and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) = 60000 mL∙g−1∙h−1. Results indicate that all of the Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts exhibit higher activity than Ni/SiO2 and covering the La2O3 shell on Ni/SiO2 significantly improves the resistance towards sintering and carbon deposition. The accelerated CH4 decomposition and CO2 dissociation over Ni/SiO2@La2O3 are close related to the metallic Ni originated from the reduction of the formed LaNiO3 perovskite, and the highest stability for a time-on-stream (TOS) of 90 h were achieve over Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation The Ni/SiO2 catalyst with a nominal Ni loading of 8 wt% was prepared by the stӧber-ammonia evaporation method, the detailed steps of which have been reported in the literature [23]. The core-shell Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts with a nominal La2O3 loading of 18 wt% were prepared via impregnation-decomposition method by using glycine, serine, and arginine as complex agent, respectively. Firstly, 0.1900 g La(NO3)3∙6H2O and a certain amount of amino acid (La(NO3)3/amino acid molar ratio = 1) were dissolved into 3.0 mL deionized water to obtain a clear solution. Then, 1.0 g Ni/SiO2 was added into the solution and further ultrasonicated for 1 h. Subsequently, the mixture was dried at 100 °C for 12 h. After repeating the above steps for three times, the grey solid was firstly burned at air to decompose the amino acid and then transferred into muffle furnace to calcine at 700 °C for 4 h to obtain the core-shell Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts, denoting as Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly, Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser, and Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Arg, respectively. The actual Ni and La2O3 contents were determined by Agilent 5110 inductively coupled plasm-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Agilent). The actual Ni content for Ni/SiO2 is 7.78 wt%, closing to the nominal value (Table 1 ). Since the same Ni-SiO2 sphere is used as core to prepare the core-shell Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts, the actual Ni contents for the latter are lower (5.4 − 5.8 wt%, Table 1) duo to the addition of La2O3 (16.5 − 17.6 wt%). 2.2 Catalysts characterization The phase information about the fresh, reduced and spent catalysts were obtained from X-ray diffraction (XRD) by using a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker), which was conducted at the scanning angle from 10° to 60° with a step size of 0.01° and an acquisition time of 0.2 s. The textural properties of the reduced catalysts were measured at –196 °C on an ASAP 2460 N2-physisorption analyzer (Micromeritics). Prior to measurement, the sample was degassed at 350 °C for 12 h. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution were determined by the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, respectively. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the reduced and spent catalysts were obtained from a JEM-2100F microscope (JEOL). The particle size distribution was obtained by counting 150 particles. The high-angle annular dark field detector (HAADF) was used to obtained the HAADF scanning TEM images (HAADF-STEM) and the elemental mappings of Si, O, Ni and La were obtained from STEM and energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX). The effect of La2O3 shell on the reduction behavior was investigated by means of H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) on an Autochem Ⅱ 2950 chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics). 40 mg of catalyst (40 – 60 mesh) was added into the U-shaped quartz tube and heated at 400 °C for 90 min with pure Ar at a flow rate of 30 mL∙min−1, eliminating the adsorbed water. After cooling down to 100 °C, the gas was switched to 10 %H2/Ar flow with a rate of 30 mL∙min−1, subsequently, the temperature was increased to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C∙min−1 and hold on for 30 min. The H2 consumption was measured by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Ni dispersion and corresponding surface area of active Ni were measured via an ASAP 2020 chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics). Firstly, 100 mg of fresh catalyst (40 – 60 mesh) was loaded at the U-shaped quartz tube and degassed at 300 °C for 6 h. Subsequently, the catalyst was heated to 750 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C∙min−1 with pure H2 (50 mL∙min−1) and hold on for 2 h, then, N2 flow with a rate of 50 mL∙min−1 was switched and the temperature was cooled down to 35 °C. After the temperature keeping stable, the chemisorption was conducted with the gas switching to pure H2. The Ni dispersion and surface area of active Ni were calculated according to the total uptake of H2. The carbon amount of the spent catalysts was determined by thermogravimetric differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC), which was conducted on an STA449 F5 thermogravimetric analyzer (Netzsch). 5 mg of spent catalyst was heated to 850 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C∙min−1 under air atmosphere. The consecutive temperature-programmed surface reaction of CH4 and CO2 (CH4/CO2-TPSR) was carried out on an Autochem Ⅱ 2950 chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics), connecting with a QIC-20 mass spectrometer (Hiden Analytical) to detect the CH4, H2, CO2, and CO. The catalyst loading and pre-treatment conditions were same as that of H2-TPR. The TPSR profile of CH4 was recorded with a ramp rate of 10 °C∙min−1 from 50 °C to 800 °C under 10%CH4/Ar flow with a rate of 30 mL∙min−1. After finishing the CH4-TPSR and switching the gas to pure Ar, the temperature was cooled down to 50 °C. Subsequently, CO2-TPSR was conducted with a ramp rate of 10 °C∙min−1 from 50 °C to 800 °C under 10%CO2/Ar flow with a rate of 30 mL∙min−1. 2.3 DRM reaction Catalytic DRM over Ni/SiO2@La2O3 was evaluated on a fixed-bed reactor (ID = 8 mm, OD = 15 mm). 100 mg of catalyst (40 – 60 mesh) was mixed with 900 mg of quartz sand (40 – 60 mesh) and located in the center of reactor, sandwiching by two pieces of quartz wool. The reaction temperature was controlled by a thermocouple located at the center of the catalyst bed layer. Prior to the catalytic evaluation, the catalyst was in-situ reduced at 750 °C for 2 h with pure H2 at a flow rate of 50 mL∙min−1, and then, the temperature was cooled down to 700 °C with a pure N2 flow at a rate of 100 mL∙min−1. Subsequently, the gas was switched to a diluted-gas free feeding gas of CH4/CO2 (molar ratio = 1) with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60000 mL∙g−1∙h−1. After eliminating the water by an ice-cold trap, the effluent gas was online analyzed by an A91 gas chromatography (PANNA Co., Ltd). The CH4, CO2 conversion (C CH4, C CO2) and H2/CO molar ratio were calculated via the equations as reported in the previous works [31,32]. The deactivation constant (k d) was calculated by means of the equation as reported in the literature [33,34]. The specific activity of CH4 and CO2 (SACH4, SACO2) was calculated by the following equation S A C H 4 o r C O 2 = C C H 4 o r C O 2 × F C H 4 o r C O 2 , i n 22.4 × N i s u r f a c e a r e a Where CCH4 or CO2, F CH4 or CO2 and Nisurface area represent the conversion, flow rate, and the active surface area of Ni, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of the fresh and reduced catalysts The detailed phase information about the catalysts was obtained from XRD (Fig. 1 a−b). Typical amorphous silica diffraction at about 23° and NiO (JCPDS 44-1159) diffractions at 37.3° and 43.3° are detected on the XRD pattern of the fresh Ni/SiO2, revealing the major Ni species is NiO, which differs from the catalyst prepared by the same method in the literature [23]. As for the fresh Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts, the broad diffraction at about 28° is assigned to the La2O3 (JCPDS 22-0369) and the intensity of SiO2 diffraction becomes weak compared to Ni/SiO2, which is attributed to the dispersed La2O3 covering on the surface of Ni/SiO2. In the case of Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly, an additional diffraction appears at 32.8°, attributable to LaNiO3 perovskite (JCPSD 34-1077), suggesting that the reaction between La2O3 and Ni species occurs during the preparation process [35]. In contrast, no obvious diffractions of LaNiO3 species are detected on Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser and Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Arg, attributable to the lower content of the formed LaNiO3, which will be verified by the H2-TPR (Fig. 3). This observation is probably explained by the structure and coordinative groups of the complexing agent. When the structure and coordinative groups of the three complexing agents are carefully examined, with the same complexing groups (-COOH, -NH2), a smaller steric hindrance is apparent for glycine and serine, which favors coordination with La3+ cations to closely contact with the Ni species on the surface of SiO2. On the other hand, relatively high amount of La2O2CO3 is formed on Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser, as confirmed by the remarkable diffraction at about 30° (JCPDS 37-0804). Concerning the other two core-shell catalysts, no obvious diffractions of La2O2CO3 are detected, which is probably due to the amount of formed La2O2CO3 is largely lower than that on Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser. The La2O2CO3 is probably originated from the reaction of La2O3 with the CO2 generated from the combustion of the complexing agent. If the molecular nature of complexing agents is taken into account, arginine possesses six carbon atoms, which are expected to release more CO2 to react with La2O3 to generate La2O2CO3, however, the amount of which is likely lower than Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser. This phenomenon suggests that the formed La2O2CO3 is independent of the content of CO2 derived from the combustion of complexing agent. As reported, La2O2CO3 is detected on the spent Ni/La2O3 with the high reaction temperature of DRM [35], indicating that the high temperature is beneficial to form La2O2CO3. Basing on this viewpoint, it is reasonable to assume that the more La2O2CO3 formed on the Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser is related to the higher decomposition temperature of serine than glycine and arginine (∼280 °C vs ∼240 °C). In the case of the reduced catalysts (Fig. 1b), pronounced diffractions at 44.5° and 52° are shown for all catalysts, attributable to the metallic Ni (JCPDS 04-0850), which indicates that the NiO and LaNiO3 species are reduced to metallic Ni with H2 at high temperature. The Ni dispersion and corresponding surface area of Ni were measured via H2-chemisorption (Table 1). Ni/SiO2 shows the highest Ni dispersion and surface area of Ni with the specific values of 13.2% and 87.85 m2∙g−1. The Ni dispersion and surface area of Ni for Ni/SiO2@La2O3 are in the range of 8.4 − 9.1% and 56 – 61 m2∙g−1, respectively. Apparently, covering La2O3 on the surface of Ni/SiO2 to form shell results in the decrease in Ni dispersion and surface area of Ni, which can be explained as the coverage of a fraction of metallic Ni by La2O3 and the blockage of porous channels. The N2-physisorption results are shown in Fig. 1c−d. All of the reduced catalysts exhibit a typical Ⅳ-type isotherm and H3-type hysteresis loop, which is typical for mesoporous structure [36,37]. The hysteresis of all catalysts is at high P/P 0 (> 0.9), suggesting the presence of large-sized mesopore > 30 nm [38]. Moreover, the adsorbed quantity sharply increases at very high P/P 0 (> 0.95), attributable to the presence of macropores (> 50 nm) [39]. The pore size distribution supported this result (Fig. 1d). The content of the pores for Ni/SiO2 is higher than that of Ni/SiO2@La2O3. Since the same Ni-SiO2 sphere is used as core to prepare the core-shell Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts, therefore, the decrease in content of pores over Ni/SiO2@La2O3 clearly confirms the blockage of porous structure by La2O3. In comparison with Ni/SiO2, the surface area of Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly, Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser, and Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Arg decreases by 62%, 80.5%, and 67.5%, respectively (Table 1). The blockage of porous structure prevents the metallic Ni within these porous channels contact with H2, hence resulting in the lower Ni dispersion. The morphology of the reduced catalysts was directly detected via TEM (Fig. 2 a−h and Fig. S1−S4). As for the reduced Ni/SiO2, black Ni nanoparticles with varied sizes randomly disperse on the surface of silica sphere, the particle size distribution of which is in the range of 4 – 16 nm with an average particle size of 6.7 ± 1.5 nm. In contrast, complete La2O3 shell with roughly same thickness are shown for the reduced Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts, as confirmed by HAADF-STEM images (Fig. S1−S4). As for Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly, Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser, Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Arg, the relative intensities of the elements clearly reflect that La2O3 covers on the surface of Ni/SiO2 to form the core-shell structure of the catalysts with an inert silica core and a thin La2O3 shell, which is very similar as the reported core-shell Ni-SiO2@CeO2 catalyst [23]. This result vigorously confirms that using impregnation-decomposition method can successfully construct core-shell Ni-based catalysts. Concerning particle size distribution, the reduced Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts exhibit almost same range as that of Ni/SiO2 (4 – 16 nm). As a result, the average particle sizes for the three catalysts are 6.9 ± 2.3 nm, 6.8 ± 2.1 nm, and 8.1 ± 2.7 nm, respectively. On the other hand, a large amount of Ni particles disperses on the outside surface of SiO2 sphere core (Fig. 2e) and the La2O3 covers on the outside surface of SiO2 core to form shell structure (Fig. 2f−h). In this context, a fraction of Ni particles covered by the formed La2O3 shell is inevitable, which leads to the decrease in Ni dispersion compared to Ni/SiO2. The above results clearly indicate that the complete La2O3 shell are successfully formed on the surface of the Ni/SiO2 by using the impregnation-decomposition method. Although these is a slight effect of La2O3 shell on the average particle size, a fraction of Ni particles dispersed on the outside surface of SiO2 core are covered by La2O3 shell, resulting in the decrease in Ni dispersion. The reduction behaviors of the fresh catalysts were investigated by means of H2-TPR (Fig. 3 a−d). A broad reduction band in the range of 250 – 750 °C is shown for Ni/SiO2 catalyst, which can be divided into three reduction peaks. Specifically, the peaks at about 350 °C, 520 °C, and about 700 °C are assigned to the reduction of NiO species with weak metal-support interaction, Ni2+ in the 1:1 nickel phyllosilicate, and Ni2+ in the 2:1 nickel phyllosilicate, respectively [23,40,41]. The latter two Ni species show strong metal-support interaction. Apparently, the reduction peak area of NiO species is higher than that of 1:1 nickel phyllosilicate and 2:1 nickel phyllosilicate, suggesting that NiO is the major Ni species in the fresh Ni/SiO2. This result is consistent with that obtained from XRD. In the case of the Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts, the reduction band is in the range of 250 – 650 °C, the specific reduction peaks of which are attributed to the reduction of NiO species with weak metal-support interaction (350 – 400 °C) and the reduction of LaNiO3 perovskite to metallic Ni (450 – 500 °C) [35,42]. The disappearance of the nickel phyllosilicate probably suggests that these Ni species react with La2O3 to form LaNiO3 perovskite and hence weaken the interaction between Ni and SiO2. Moreover, the reduction peak area of LaNiO3 generally decreases following the order: Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly (1.3519) > Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser (1.2633) > Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Arg (0.9447). This observation clearly illustrates the content of the formed LaNiO3 perovskite and the metallic Ni reduced from this species gradually decreased following the above order. The difference of LaNiO3 between the three core-shell catalysts can be explained as the structural characteristics of the used complexing agents, which has been discussed in XRD. Therefore, the above results of H2-TPR indicate that LaNiO3 perovskite with different content is formed on the three core-shell Ni-based catalysts and constructing La2O3 shell can affect the reduction behaviors of Ni species. 3.2 Catalytic performance for DRM over Ni/SiO2@La2O3 La2O3 shell can exert a significant influence on DRM performance (Fig. 4 a−d). Regardless of the catalysts tested, the CO2 activity is higher than CH4 activity, attributable to the occurrence of reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS, H2 + CO2 → H2O + CO Δ H 298 K 0 = + 41 k J · m o l − 1 ) [43,44]. As a result, the H2/CO molar ratio is in the range of 0.5 -0.75, lower than 1. Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly, Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser, and Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Arg exhibit great CH4 activity with the specific value of 23.9 mmol∙(min∙m2∙g)−1Ni, 24.3 mmol∙(min∙m2∙g)−1Ni and 21.8 mmol∙(min∙m2∙g)−1Ni, which is higher than that of Ni/SiO2 (17.8 mmol∙(min∙m2∙g)−1Ni). Furthermore, constructing La2O3 shell enhances the catalytic stability, as confirmed by the lower k d for Ni/SiO2@La2O3 (0.019 – 0.028 h−1) than that of Ni/SiO2 (0.051 h−1). Apparently, the above results vigorously confirm that La2O3 shell can significantly improve the catalytic activity and stability. 3.3 Discussion As shown in DRM performance evaluation, significantly improved activity and stability are obtained, illustrating strongly promotional impact of La2O3 shell on the catalytic performance. Therefore, in order to verify the effect of La2O3 shell on anti-sintering and anti-coking capacities as well as DRM performance, a comprehensive discussion together with the characterization results of the fresh, reduced, and spent catalysts is provided. All of the Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts show better catalytic stability than Ni/SiO2, which is attributed to the improved anti-sintering and anti-coking capacities, as confirmed by XRD, TG-DSC, and TEM (Fig. 5 a−b and Fig. 2A1−H1). After the DRM performance evaluation with a time-on-stream (TOS) of 24 h, all of the spent catalysts exhibit a stronger intensity of Ni diffraction than the reduced counterparts (Fig. 1b vs Fig. 5a), indicating the occurrence of sintering. Apparently, the level of the increased intensity of Ni diffraction for Ni/SiO2@La2O3 is lower than that of Ni/SiO2, which proves that La2O3 shell can enhance the anti-sintering capacity owing to the confinement effect of the shell structure [23–25]. This view is also supported by the particle size distribution and the average particle size obtained from TEM images. The particle size distribution of Ni/SiO2 increases from 4 − 16 nm to 5 − 30 nm (Fig. 2a vs Fig. 2a1). As a result, the average particle size increase from 6.7 ± 1.5 nm to 10.1 ± 3.6 nm (Table 1 vs Table 2 ). In contrast, the particle size distribution of Ni/SiO2@La2O3 increases from 4 − 16 nm to 5 − 20 nm (Fig. 2b−d vs Fig. 2b1−d1) with a lower level of the increase in average particle size (Table 1 vs Table 2). Concerning the anti-coking capacity, TG-DSC results clearly confirm that La2O3 shell significantly improves the resistance towards carbon deposition (Fig. 5b). The amount of carbon formed on Ni/SiO2@La2O3 is considerably lower than that on Ni/SiO2 (Table 2). It is should be noted that no carbon forms on the surface of Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Arg, suggesting the better resistance towards carbon deposition. Considering the neglected carbon deposition, the deactivation of Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Arg is majorly caused by sintering of Ni particle. On the other hand, although the oxidization of carbon formed on the spent catalysts occurs in the range of 500 – 700 °C, there is obvious difference on the specific gasification temperature. The DSC peaks is at 550 °C, 570 °C, and 510 °C for respective Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly, Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser, and Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Arg, significantly lower than that of Ni/SiO2 (660 °C), which proves that the carbon species formed on Ni/SiO2@La2O3 is easier eliminated by air than the carbon species formed on Ni/SiO2. Therefore, the enhanced anti-coking capacity is reflected in reducing the amount of carbon deposition and suppressing the formation of more inert carbon species. Moreover, the high thermal stability of the La2O3 shell, as confirmed by TEM (Fig. 2b−h vs Fig. 6 b−h), is also an important factor for the better catalytic stability. When the catalytic activity is considered, the Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts exhibit higher CH4 activity compared to Ni/SiO2 (Fig. 4). However, the surface area of Ni for the three catalysts is lower than Ni/SiO2 (Table 1). In order to further clarify the reason for the high activity, the CH4 decomposition and CO2 dissociation over the catalysts were investigated via the consecutive CH4/CO2-TPSR (Fig. 7 a−d). Apparently, all Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts exhibit a good activity for CH4 decomposition that the dissociation peak centered at 515 °C. In contrast, Ni/SiO2 is less active for CH4 decomposition, as confirmed by the higher dissociation peak at 540 °C. The intensity of CH4 dissociation peak for Ni/SiO2@La2O3 is also higher than that of Ni/SiO2. Moreover, the same trend is shown for the H2 peak. These results vigorously prove that La2O3 shell promotes the CH4 decomposition, and hence, Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts show higher CH4 activity. Subsequently, CO2-TPSR was conducted to evaluate the elimination capacity of CO2 towards surface carbon originated from CH4 decomposition. As expected, the Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts display a CO2 dissociation peak centered at 610 °C, which is lower than that of Ni/SiO2 (615 °C), the intensity of which is also stronger than Ni/SiO2. This result confirms that the La2O3 shell simultaneously promotes the activation of CO2, which is also supported by the lower temperature and stronger intensity of CO peak for Ni/SiO2@La2O3. Based on the above results, the high active for DRM over Ni/SiO2@La2O3 is assigned to the accelerated CH4 decomposition and the better anti-coking capacity is explained as the improved gasification of carbon by promoting CO2 dissociation. Therefore, the Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts show a good long-term stability with the lower k d of 0.00537 h−1, 0.00651 h−1, and 0.00583 h−1, and the best stability is achieved over Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly (Fig. 8 a−d). Moreover, after the long-term stability testing, the average Ni particle sizes of Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly, Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser, and Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Arg increase to 9.5 nm, 11.4 nm and 11.9 nm, respectively (Fig. 8e), which only encounter slight sintering compared to the spent catalysts with a TOS of 24 h (Table 2). This result confirms that the anti-sintering capacity of Ni/SiO2 is effectively enhanced by constructing La2O3 shell. Although the reaction time is prolonged to 90 h, the amounts of carbon deposition for Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly, Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser, and Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Arg are still lower than that of Ni/SiO2 with a TOS of 24 h (Fig. 8f), which vigorously confirms that constructing La2O3 shell can significantly enhance the anti-coking capacity. In order to clarify which metallic Ni species promotes the CH4 and CO2 activation, the association analysis between the different metallic Ni (represented by the reduction peak area of NiO and LaNiO3, respectively) and CH4 activity, particle size, surface area of Ni, intensity of H2 peak, and intensity of CO peak is conducted to further verify whether there is a close connection between the metallic Ni from LaNiO3 and the above-mentioned properties as well as the activation of CH4 and CO2 (Fig. 9 ). The particle size displays a rough increasing trend with increasing the content of the Ni reduced from NiO but the corresponding surface of Ni shows a contrary trend. In contrast, the increasing surface of Ni roughly follows with the increase in the content of Ni reduced from LaNiO3. These results suggest that the reduction of LaNiO3 to metallic Ni can improve the Ni dispersion. Moreover, the variation of CH4 activity follows the same trend as that of Ni reduced from LaNiO3 but is contrary to the Ni reduced from NiO. As expected, an increasing trend of the intensity of H2 peak and CO2 peak is shown for the three Ni/SiO2@La2O3 as increasing the content of metallic Ni from LaNiO3, which vigorously confirm that the Ni sites originated form the reduction of LaNiO3 perovskite are more active for CH4 decomposition and CO2 dissociation. As a result, the CH4 activity roughly follows the same trend as that of CH4 decomposition. On the other hand, it is should be noted that Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly possesses slightly higher content of LaNiO3 than Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Ser but shows nearly same CH4 activity, which is probably affected by other factors apart from the metallic Ni reduced from LaNiO3. This assumption is worth to deeply investigated in the further work. As discussed above, the metallic Ni reduced from LaNiO3 perovskite originated from the reaction of La2O3 shell with the Ni species of Ni/SiO2 can improve the surface area of Ni and promote CH4 decomposition and CO2 dissociation. Based on the experimental results presented in this study, Ni/SiO2@La2O3 show higher CH4 activity and enhanced anti-coking capacity. Moreover, the anti-sintering capacity is enhanced by the confinement effect of La2O3 shell. Therefore, the core-shell NiSiO2@La2O3 catalysts display improved DRM activity and stability than Ni/SiO2. In comparison with the Ni-based catalysts reported recently (Table 3 ) [4,45–48], the core-shell Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts shows relatively high activity and stability under the high GHSV of 60000 mL∙g−1∙h−1 with a diluted-gas free feeding gas of CH4/CO2 (molar ratio = 1), verifying the promotional effect of La2O3 shell on the DRM performance over Ni/SiO2. More importantly, in the light of detailed characterizations, it is proved that the promotional effect of La2O3 shell on CH4 and CO2 activation is related to the Ni reduced from the formed LaNiO3 perovskite, which offers a guidance on the design of high-performance core-shell Ni-based catalysts. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of core-shell Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts were prepared by impregnation-decomposition method with using three kinds of amino acid as complexing agent, and the DRM catalyzed by these catalysts was comparatively studied to understand the promotional effect of La2O3 shell. La2O3 covers on the surface of Ni/SiO2 to form complete La2O3 shell and further reacts with the Ni species to form LaNiO3 perovskite, the amount of which is adjusted by using the glycine, serine, arginine as fuel, respectively. All of the Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts exhibit higher CH4 activity than Ni/SiO2, attributable to the accelerated CH4 activation. As expected, the catalytic stability of Ni/SiO2@La2O3 is significantly improved, and the highest stability with a TOS of 90 h is achieved over Ni/SiO2@La2O3-Gly, which can be well explained as the improved anti-sintering and anti-coking capacities. The enhanced anti-sintering capacity is attributed to the confinement effect of La2O3 shell on suppress Ni agglomeration. The consecutive temperature-programmed surface reaction results vigorously confirm that constructing La2O3 shell simultaneously promote the CH4 decomposition and CO2 dissociation, which is the significantly important reason for the higher DRM activity and better anti-coking capacity. More importantly, the promotional effect of La2O3 shell on CH4 decomposition and CO2 dissociation is closely related to the metallic Ni form the reduction of the formed LaNiO3 perovskite. These understanding provides an important guidance for design a high-performance core-shell Ni-based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The core-shell Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts were prepared by impregnation-decomposition method, and were comparatively evaluated for dry reforming of methane (DRM) under the severe conditions of 700 °C, 0.1 MPa, CH4/CO2 molar ratio of 1 and gas hourly space velocity of 60000 mL∙g−1∙h−1. La2O3 covers on the surface of Ni/SiO2 to form complete shell and reacts with Ni species to form LaNiO3 perovskite. The La2O3 shell blocks a fraction of porous structure and covers a part of Ni nanoparticles, resulting in the decrease in Ni dispersion. The Ni/SiO2@La2O3 catalysts exhibit higher CH4 activity (21.8 – 24.3 mmol∙(min∙m2∙g)−1Ni) than Ni/SiO2 (17.8 mmol∙(min∙m2∙g)−1Ni), attributable to the accelerated CH4 activation over the Ni sites on these catalysts. The catalytic stability of Ni/SiO2@La2O3 is significantly improved (k d = 0.0198 – 0.0276 h−1 vs k d = 0.0512 h−1 for Ni/SiO2), which can be well explained as the enhanced anti-sintering and anti-coking capacities. The enhanced anti-sintering capacity is attributed to the confinement effect of La2O3 shell on suppressing sintering. The consecutive temperature-programmed surface reaction results confirm that La2O3 shell simultaneously promotes the CH4 decomposition and CO2 dissociation, which is the significantly important reason for the high DRM activity and good anti-coking capacity. The promotional effect of La2O3 shell on CH4 decomposition and CO2 dissociation is closely related to the metallic Ni originated from the reduction of the formed LaNiO3 perovskite. These understanding provides an important guidance for design a high-performance core-shell Ni-based catalysts.
